content: On Github, @Sebastien Gouezel disagrees with notation for continuous k-linear alternating maps introduced by @Heather Macbeth. Could you please agree about notation for (a) continuous alternating maps from E to F; (b) k-forms on a manifold (a.k.a. smooth sections of the bundle of continuous alternating maps)?
I don't care about notaion as long as it's easier to type than the full name.

To add some details, in the PR the notation Œõ^Œπ‚üÆR; M; N‚üØ means: the space of R-multilinear alternate maps on M^Œπ with values in N. My problem with this notation is that, usually, Œõ^n E is not a space of n-multilinear maps on E, but the space of alternate n-tensors on E. While the space of n-multilinear alternate maps on E would rather be Œõ^n (E^*).

This being said, I don't really have a good notation. Maybe E [Œõ^Œπ]‚ÜíL[ùïú] F?
(by analogy with E [√ón]‚ÜíL[ùïú] F for n-multilinear continuous maps from E to F that we already use in calculus).
What if we introduce a scoped instance CoeSort Nat sending n to Fin n?
Then we can use E [√óŒπ]‚ÜíL[ùïú] F for multilinear maps and E [Œõ^Œπ]‚ÜíL[ùïú] F for alternating maps without explicitly adding Fin.

Matrix (Fin n) (Fin m) E would also look nicer using that (though often you want to not restrict your matrices to just use Fin).
If it's scoped and doesn't lead to problems most of the time, it's worth a try.

Aren't there two orthogonal issues here?

  • Notation for multivariate maps that doesn't look like it is alternating maps
  • Using n or Fin n
The first issue is "notation for alternating maps that doesn't mix space with its dual".
Concerning the latter, I have no experience with this part of the library. But would it be worth working with (n : Type) [FinType n] instead of Fin n?

And when we actually use it in analysis, we mostly use Œπ = Fin n.
